Using TreeDist to calculate tree similarity

Martin R. Smith

2019-09-11

Source: vignettes/Using-TreeDist.Rmd
Using-TreeDist.Rmd

Loading trees

Instructions for loading phylogenetic trees into R can be found in a separate vignette. For these examples, we’ll enter two simple trees by hand:

tree1 <- ape::read.tree(text='(A, ((B, ((C, D), (E, F))), (G, ((H, I), (J, K)))));')
tree2 <- ape::read.tree(text='(A, ((B, ((C, D), (E, (J, K)))), (G, ((H, I), F))));')

Calculating distances

We can calculate distances between pairs of trees using the TreeDist package.
First we’ll install the package.

We can either install the stable version from the CRAN repository:

install.packages('TreeDist')

or the development version, from GitHub – which will contain the latest features but may not be as extensively tested:

devtools::install_github('ms609/TreeDist')

Then we’ll load the package in to R’s working environment:

library('TreeDist')

Now the package’s functions are available within R. Let’s proceed to calculate some tree distances.

Pairs of trees

Calculating the distance between two trees is as simple as:

distance <- TreeDistance(tree1, tree2)

The convenience function TreeDistance returns the variation of clustering information between two trees, normalized against the total information content of all partitions. For more on different tree distance metrics, see the tree distance vignette.

Multiple comparisons

If you have more than two trees to compare, you can send a list of trees to the distance comparison function, whether of class list or multiPhylo. The function will then calculate the distance between each tree in the first list and each tree in the second.

oneTree <- ape::rtree(11)
twoTrees <- structure(list(ape::rtree(11), ape::rtree(11)), class='multiPhylo')
threeTrees <- list(ape::rtree(11), ape::rtree(11), ape::rtree(11))

TreeDistance(oneTree, twoTrees)
## [1] 0.2065474 0.1837730
TreeDistance(twoTrees, threeTrees)
##           [,1]      [,2]      [,3]
## [1,] 0.2851893 0.2292391 0.2767812
## [2,] 0.1443049 0.2609740 0.2521410

Visualizing a matching

Generalized Robinson-Foulds metrics, such as the variation of clustering information, rely on matching each split within a tree with another split in the other tree. We can view an optimal matching:

VisualizeMatching(VariationOfClusteringInfo, tree1, tree2)

This shows the eight splits in tree 1, and the paired splits in tree two.
Each split is labelled with a measure of its similarity, which is its contribution to the total tree distance score.

We can view this information in a format accessible for further examination in R with:

VariationOfClusteringInfo(tree1, tree2, reportMatching = TRUE)
## [1] 126.5108
## attr(,"pairScores")
##            [,1]       [,2]      [,3]       [,4]      [,5]      [,6]
## [1,] 2.61837154 0.82205391  3.851519 0.25888416  2.906522 1.1435131
## [2,] 1.14351309 2.37666097  5.084667 0.01717359  2.138909 0.3758998
## [3,] 2.90652237 3.85151941 10.855447 1.49203203  0.932821 2.1389091
## [4,] 0.02113229 0.02113229  0.932821 0.60740310  0.932821 0.1985161
## [5,] 0.82205391 0.11480874  2.906522 0.78478686  3.851519 2.3766610
## [6,] 0.05444064 0.05444064  2.138909 1.66941580  5.084667 0.5199752
## [7,] 3.85151941 2.90652237  0.932821 1.49203203  0.932821 5.0846673
## [8,] 2.90652237 3.85151941  0.932821 6.88098491 10.855447 2.1389091
##            [,7]      [,8]
## [1,] 0.25888416  2.906522
## [2,] 0.01717359  2.138909
## [3,] 1.49203203  0.932821
## [4,] 0.60740310  0.932821
## [5,] 0.78478686  3.851519
## [6,] 1.66941580  5.084667
## [7,] 6.88098491 10.855447
## [8,] 1.49203203  0.932821
## attr(,"matching")
## Optimal assignment:
## 1 => 1, 2 => 2, 3 => 3, 4 => 4, 5 => 6, 6 => 7, 7 => 8, 8 => 5
## attr(,"matchedSplits")
## [1] "B C D E F : A G H I J K => B C D E J K : A F G H I"
## [2] "C D E F : A B G H I J K => C D E J K : A B F G H I"
## [3] "C D : A B E F G H I J K => C D : A B E F G H I J K"
## [4] "E F : A B C D G H I J K => E J K : A B C D F G H I"
## [5] "G H I J K : A B C D E F => F G H I : A B C D E J K"
## [6] "H I J K : A B C D E F G => F H I : A B C D E G J K"
## [7] "H I : A B C D E F G J K => H I : A B C D E F G J K"
## [8] "J K : A B C D E F G H I => J K : A B C D E F G H I"

Here, the pairScores attribute lists the score of each possible matching of splits.

We can identify the splits with:

splits <- IdentifySplits(TreeSearch::Tree2Splits(tree2))
splits
##                        14                        15 
## "B C D E J K : A G H I F" "C D E J K : A B G H I F" 
##                        16                        17 
## "C D : A B E J K G H I F" "E J K : A B C D G H I F" 
##                        18                        19 
## "J K : A B C D E G H I F" "G H I F : A B C D E J K" 
##                        20                        21 
## "H I F : A B C D E J K G" "H I : A B C D E J K G F"

The names of the splits correspond to the number of the nodes in the original tree:

par(mar = rep(0, 4))
plot(tree2)
ape::nodelabels()
ape::nodelabels(splits, as.integer(names(splits)), 
                adj=c(1.1, -0.2), cex=0.8, frame='none')

  • Provide context for tree distances
